reviews.review_text: There is a lot I like and do recommend it; HOWEVER, and there is a lot I don't like about this game.  The good parts:  just love the graphics! Love the audio! Love love love the concept behind the whole premise of the game! It's genius! Almost everything about it is just fun. The different characters being animals and their traits. etc. This has so much potential for expansion it isn't funny. The whole game as it is now could be one small room in a whole castle or kingdom. and jsut a small part of the story. (sorry in game development so get too excited about the potentials.. feature creep) Anyway, the like part of this is so broad that it's hard to put it in a few words and I don't have time or the finger durability to write it all down. I love the fact that it's difficult to master. ... but the game is too random card wise to get really good at it or turning situations. I love that you can win in different ways. like I said .. this game has so much genius in it.    However, in the hopes that the dev team sees some of this I will detail a little more in the 'don't like' side of things. Because I want to keep playing!  First of all, the games are not short most of the time, and that is good, but there is no way to save a game and come back to it later. If you have to stop and quit due to life, you loose all progress. I don't need a bunch of saves to cheat with. I just want to save to come back to later. It took me almost 3 hours to play one game. Sometimes I don't have that long to play but don't want to screw myself out of playing because I don't have 3 hours. Online play, well doh, no need for it there but locally, that is a feature I'm frankly appauled isn't in there yet. That is an industry standard for any tabletop or turn based game. ... in fact most all games.  A couple of times I played a card, for example, one that takes one prestige from each player. palyed the card no problem, and everyone still had all their prestige and I got 0. There are a few cards in there that are similar that seem to be buggy in general or buggy to one character.. but it isn't consistant enough to give you a bug report with any helpful info in it to track it down.   The randomness of the dice and cards are a bit too random. characters really don't get to build and use their strengths and weaknesses.. wait... Thane has no weaknesses (for example)... and always has money and prestige even if you take it all away. Even if he has an item of some sort. doesn't matter the game, whether he has city income or not or hasn't even gone treasure hunting, etc. Even if he gets killed 4 times in a row with no source of income , he's always got plenty of gold and presitge. LOL!! That kind of needs to be looked at. Makes for a great challenge if you got the right attitude, but even if you do, after a while it gets old.   I know unlocking jewelry and stuff helps you customize it a little bit but honestly, it's in areas that don't help that much in most characters... not all.. but most. What good is stealth in the city at one part of the day when it's likely they saw you go in there.. >,< It's just an example of the many things. Sure it might come in handy a sliver of the time but it really doesn't make you feel compelled to unlock much of anything... and there is no progression at all in any way to make you feel like you are playing more than a same scenario board game.   In the game you have to stay almost completely rot free to survive or go full rot.. you can't really play the middle of the road and have much of a chance of winning anything other than prestige or by stones.  I will have to say though, even with all the 'dark side' comments, it's worth 15 dollars... but if improvements aren't made soon, honestly I wouldn't pay 10 for it even as beautiful and artful as it is. The flaws are big gotcha's .. something as simple as a 'sorry you can't save your game and come back to it' is HUGE!!  I really hope this keeps progressing I love it and do recommend it.   Edit: It will save your progress in single player, but be aware there is no message that it will do so.

If RNG hates you, you can't do anything about it. * Matches are too short - 20 turns, 24 at custom rules, and any attack that wounds the King cuts that further down. * Next to no settings, specifically graphics, language (it always takes the setting from steam), ans such.  Overall, the game has great potential but it needs fixing. Right now it has little to boast aside from the good looks.

Armello did something for me that no other game has been able to do effectively. It made tabletop strategy seem accessible and fun for me.   The tutorial does its job well. The way it presents the various gameplay concepts, staggered through different characters to show different approaches to the game, really helped make the ideas stick. While Armello has some fairly complex aspects to it, I was never left feeling intimidated as I often am by other games in this genre.   The art style is gorgeous and I feel this is one of the most beautiful games I've played in a long time. Despite basically being pawns on a board, each hero has its own distinct personality, which I personally find necessary for a game to be engaging and to have any longevity.  Though I'm only a few games in and can't comment on it at length, I do like the inclusion of a progression system. Being able to unlock items for my characters that allow me to alter their play style gives me more incentive to keep coming back.   The pace of the game can be a bit slow at times, since you not only have to wait for other players' turns but also the king's guards as well as any banes that have emerged on the map, but I feel that's really a minor issue.   Overall, I'm really happy with Armello so far and look forward to trying out the upcoming multiplayer ladder.

Pretty disappointing.  I'm a big fan of board games, and was recommended this by a video reviewer I put good faith in.  The game is gorgeous, and has a lot of charm, however the gameplay just doesn't hold up.  Maybe it's because I listen to a lot of podcasts on game design, but this game was a fail. There's way too much luck involved, and most strategy you can conjure up hardly matters. The first two games I played I just happened to win because I was doing quests and playing cards when I could.   A good game boils down to making interesting decisions, but when playing this game there's very few to be had. Most of it doesn't even matter. Do I pick the quest that gives me a 30% chance to get a Spirit stone and a spirit that I won't use, or do I pick the quest that gives me a not useful companion that gives the health I'll probably need?   Do I win by killing the king because I happened to get some rot cards and died to the birds? Or do I kill the king because I got lucky enough to get two spirit stones from the dungeons and it was super easy to get the rest? It's just horribly dull.  Gameplay boils down to. 'Pick a character, use amulets/rings to give them small advantages.' This gives you the illusion that there's strategies to explore, but in actuality it ends up more like this:   Go to quest. Hopefully get something good out of it, or don't 'risk' it. (But good luck having any sort of a chance if you don't.) Explore dungeons, get random stuff, or don't. Get into fights. Win/Lose them depending on what equipment you happened to get and how lucky you were on your rolls. Someone on the board gets enough Rot/Spirit Stones/OP equips to kill king. Very little you can do to stop them. They fight the king and usually win. Sometimes they'll die in the process and someone else who did nothing all game will win instead. Game's over.  I hope more people explore the interesting design space there is in a digital board game in the future, but this game felt like all style and not substance.  If you're looking for a super casual game and have a high tolerance for swingy gameplay to play with a few buddies, then this is the game for you.  If you want something anything deeper than that, look elsewhere.  2.5/5

I've played quite a lot while this game was in early-acces and finally decided to create a review since it's just fully released. So here's my quick review :D  Pros: - A lot of strategy: There is a time limit of around 1.5 minute online per turn. You really need this time to complete your turn properly. Every move is a decision.  - Great artwork: The game just looks absolutely amazing. Especially the cartoonish artwork in the 'fight scenes'. - RNG: The game works with random cards you get in your hand, this makes every match a different experience. The fight system works with dices, so you can get lucky or very unlucky, but overall, the player with the best odds wins most of the battles.  The RNG part is something you may or may not like. I personally liked the RNG part, because the winner of the match is still mostly decided by skill, not RNG.   Cons: - Slow: In an online game you are waiting most of the time. This isn't that much of a problem since you can still play cards while it's not your turn, but still, one game takes about one hour.  - Matchmaking: Getting into an online match can take some time. EDIT: As of now, the wait timers are very reasonable.  Overall this game is worth your money if you like Strategy games and can enjoy the RNG parts.

Armello is a visually beautiful, tightly designed, quick-to-play adventure. I tend to play by myself, but multiplayer is functional and offers a bit of a different experience. I love this game.  It's rare to find a game that packs so much, narratively and in terms of interesting mechanics, into a 90-minute session. All of Armello's characters are quite different from each other, and there's a lot of variety in how you set up your character to start. Once the game begins, though, it's time to be flexible, because with dice fights and card draws, you've got to enjoy rolling with the punches. I disagree with the reviewer who said that everything is determined in the first few turns -- things can, and do, change suddenly. If you want to set things up perfectly and then have them go exactly according to plan, you'll be thwarted.  Armello is well worth the money, and so is the expansion. It's fun, thrilling, sometimes heartbreaking, and just technically really well done. The studio crossed their t's and it shows, and I hope they continue expanding it in the future. I would definitely throw down cash for an RPG set in the same world.

5/5 Stars  I'm one of the original backers for the game, and I'm very satisfied with having backed this project. It is exactly what I thought it would be in all of the early material, and it is just as much fun as I had hoped.   This is very much a board game that I don't think could reasonably exist in physical form due to its stealth, ambush, and quest mechanics, and thus is a unique experience for board gamers and something that should be added to any collection.  The characters and plot quests are reminiscent of Arkham Horror, as is the concept of multiple types of victory. I love Arkham Horror for its story and chacters, so of course I consider these to be good characteristics to emulate.  I love that the prestige leader gets to choose between two potentially very bad options. It provides a reason to stay competitive about prestige even if you're trying for a different kind of victory.  The AI is challenging and aggressive, so getting a victory is not a cakewalk and feels more like competing with other real players.  As for the graphics and music, I think the music is perfect for the game, and the animate card graphics are lovely. If I want to be picky, I think the 3D animations could have been better. They're a bit too sharp and block defined around the edges, though the movements are smooth. They're a bit reminiscent of early 3D animations in games rather than being on par with where we are right now. But in terms of turning out a great game on a budget and on schedule, I think the simpler animations were a good choice.  It's also worth mentioning that if you like achievement hunting in games, this is definitely a game for you, as even if you feel you're going to lose the quest to rule Armello, you can focus on completing some of the Steam achievements, which means even a game where luck is not on your side can make you feel that you accomplished something.  If you are a board gamer or know someone who is, I highly recommend picking up Armello.

Having watched this game through Early Access iterations and release, I can say that the game is fun and also that the devs care that it is in a good state.  HARDWARE GTX 970, Phenom II X6 @ 3.2ghz, 16gb RAM, SSD Mouse and Keyboard  Steam Controller -  Works great , see below.  Performance - The game never drops below 60FPS and looks great 98% of the time. Minor texture flickering may occur and occasional audio performance issues from using the newly released Steam Controlled and Big Picture mode it seems. The game is being constantly updated. I have experienced NMA (no more action) bugs only twice or so in my 74 hours of gameplay, some other minor bugs after its release from early access as well but the release is solid and you should not experience any real issues either. Netplay seems to work very reliably and has Steam integration for playing with friends.  Gameplay - Armello is more or less a tabletop board game where you control one of several semi-customizable heroes in your quest to be the new king. This is achieved by acruing the most prestige when the king dies of a magical corruption (or failed regicide), killing the king and surviving, or by collecting four artefacts required to cure him. You have several decks of cards with themes of equipment, magic, and subterfuge, which you can draw and play towards your goal. There's choices on how to progress your character, risks to weigh against rewards, and plenty of tussles to be had with the other players as you fight each other along the way. The thematics in this game are all wonderful, and the art, music, and visuals all contribute to the great presentation. The duration of a full-length online game is about 45-90 minutes depending on how long people take on their turns, and it can be less if a player achieves one of the other victory conditions,  But is it fun? I think so. The game has a strong element of RNG. Random board terrain, cards drawn, AI character movement, fickle dice rolls, and other players strangely unpredictable behavior all contribute towards making the game seem a crapshoot. One of the more prevalent complaints I have seen is how RNG heavy the game can be. But strategy does exist and a large part of it is being adaptive to the state of the game and trying to sway the odds in your favor. Knowing what decks to draw out of to try get the right cards you need, knowing what your objective should be for that phase of the game, and knowing what victory condition you should be working towards (and not just wandering the board aimlessly), these are all important and more. True, this isn't always going to work, but the game would probably be a lot more boring if every player was able to run consistent strategies, or only a few consistent strategies existed. The randomness of the game gives you more unpredictable 'oh-my-god that just happened' moments. It wont require any sort of grand strategy game knowledge to enjoy yourself either, so if you like to just play by the seat of your pants you can do that too. I think most importantly, if you can be a bit laid pack and not get upset over the outcome of a dice roll going completely wrong and maybe even losing you the game every now and then, you will have a good time.   All in all, its a great game. I've played 75 hours and loved them all, and I hope to play many more. TL;DR- This game is awesome for the first couple of playthroughs. If you don't have friends to play with, playing the same game gets old very, very quickly. The lack of game types or customization destroys the replayability of this game, and therefore it's only a great game for the first few hours, and I would recommend spending your money elsewhere. I would definitely change my opinion if they opened up more options on customization to allow epic style games.  Looking at the graphics and the concept of this game, I was really pumped to get it. With that being said, I probably had higher expectations than what I should have going in. This game is a board game, plain and simple, and the first few playthroughs of the game that I had with each hero were awesome, since I learned the strengths and weaknesses of each hero, the randomness of cards and dice rolling, and the strategies of how to navigate the board as well as developing an overall strategy to win the game, on top of all of the 'randomness'. (Quests are random, with random bonus rewards, with a % chance to GET that bonus reward). All in all I really liked the luck aspect of the game balanced with the strategy aspect of the game, and the music and the artstyle really help making play the overall game fun, even if I feel that the AI turns take a bit longer than I would want to. Overall, the gameplay experience for the first couple of playthroughs was amazing.  With that being said, I tend to enjoy games where I can change the parameters around to make the game more interesting once I understand the and have a decent grasp of the games basic concepts. I've sadly grown fond of being able to change gameplay aspects due to modding. In custom games you can switch it up, but at the same time I would really enjoy being able to change more aspects of the game to get a different experience each time. For instance..  -I would love to be able to change the size of the map, or the amount of movement my hero can make on a turn. I'd really like there to be more than 2 maps to play on, since this gets very old, very fast.  -I would really like to be able to choose if I could equip more items on a hero. Having 3 helps with strategy, but I would love to get into crazy battles where I can have 8 or 9 dice with a few spells I could cast and extra cards to throw away.   -I would love to be able to purchase specific items or followers for a significant amount of gold to reduce the luck factor of a game. I've played a game where certain AI can get incredibly lucky early on with items and followers, and completely dominate the game. Purchasing a key item or follower for 10 gold or 10 magic would make the game feel less luck dependent, where at least I could have a chance at being able to augment my heroes strategy.   -I'd like to be able to choose in a custom game where only certain victory-types are allowed. Creating an epic long game without rot on the king just makes the AI go for a stones victory every time, versus a long drawn out game. I would also like there to be an option to be able to choose the amount of quests you can get before you are directed towards the king, so playing a longer game becomes viable.  Basically, without customization factors and with only 2 maps to play on, if you are not playing with friends, this game becomes pretty old, pretty fast. I guess I have a higher bar, since I'm used to playing games that allow modding, and that may not be fair, but there are many games out there with much longer staying power.

It's an interesting strategy game where you have to plan ahead, set your goals, and a blessing from RNJesus to bestow you a victory, but it's no real loss to lose-unless you're the type to get unreasonably salty about videogames, in which case I would advise you to turn off your computer and take a soulsearching walk through the park.  If I had to pick what I like so much about the game, it would have to be the attention to the lore, and even the characters, who all have different ways to say the predefined ways of talking. I rather appreciate how that IS the only way to communicate with other players, outside of messaging them personally after the game is finished. The visuals are stunning as well, and my only real regret is, one day I will have seen all of the cards, and I will be left wanting more of their interesting and frankly, entertaining visuals. The styles are wide and varried where they should be-the startup splash screen looks like a tapestry, battle animations are fun to look at, and the 3D models look and feel the part of the whimsical, but dark tabletop boardgame, and the UI and navigation is fun to gawk at whilst I plot against my friends.  I also appreciate how I can unlock things in the game-like the winter dice, but for those who wish to purchase things, they have a quick and easy option for that. No microtransactions here, and the DLC actually will add an entire clan to the runnings to switch up gameplay, which I can only hope, will add to the longevity of the game itself. Armello is a board game brought to life in virtual form and it is done beautifully which is a credit to the developers as board games rarely convert well to a video game format. The game is set in a mythical fantasy kingdom of medieval animal characters, initially of which four were selectable but another four have been added since. There are four factions that represent different species, rats, rabbits, wolves and bears. The rat faction is home to charismatic sneaky types who suit the player that values cleverness and cunning (I always play as Mercurio for this reason) the rabbit faction is home to nobility who fare best at exploring and unearthing valuable artifacts, the wolf faction consists of brave warriors, suitable for players who value honour and battle and the bear faction consists of druids who suit players that prefer to use magic. All four factions and the characters who represent them are well balanced and give the game a good amount of variety in it's functionality.   The object of the game is to dethrone the corrupted King (who naturally is a Lion) and usurp the throne for your own faction. The land has been swept by an arcane sickness that has brought about large ravens that leave death and destruction in their wake, the corruption they spread is a blight that darkens the souls of creatures it touches, which is why the King must be dethroned. The game takes place across a day and night cycle which alternate every turn, each night the King takes a point of corruption which weakens his health but makes his ability to fight more devestating. There are four ways to win in Armello, you can kill the King yourself thus dethroning him in person, you can opt to be a little more guileful and gather prestige so that you are selected to be heir should the King die due to corruption rather than player intervention, you can collect four spirit stones that can be used to cure the King of corruption so he can be banished or you can gain as much corruption as possible through evil deeds which will give you a better chance at killing the King. As the game plays out you move freely around the board as many spaces each turn as your character abilities allow for, you collect cards that come in various forms that affect yourself, other players and the board in various ways. You can also opt to go on quests that come with their own rewards and add a good deal of role playing and flavour to the game. Should you come across an opposing player you can opt to battle them and if you do you get given the opportunity to burn any cards you don't want and each card will be converted into a dice that represents whatever burn ability the card had alongside it's own ability, this can come in the form of combat and various other things that will affect how the battles play out. There are honestly so many unique functions and things to do in this game that to go into all of them would take too much time, but for a game that lasts around an hour per session it really manages to suck you in and offer you a great deal of things to do without ever seeming too rules heavy or complex, which really gives it great appeal to both hardcore board game players and newcomers alike.  I really, really like Armello, it's a beautiful game with fantastic artwork, design and enough tactical depth to keep you coming back for more. I play a number of board games with friends and Armello has outstayed many of them, which is quite the feat for a virtual board game. If you have any interest in board style games at all or were just looking for something to play with friends and family I highly recommend Armello, it's quickly become one of my favourites.

Armello: Haphazard Regicide  Ever wanted to kill a king? No? Oh Well, ugh, this is significantly more awkward, isnt it? I guess er, you know, forget I said anything.  SoDo you like anthropomorphic animals? Yes? Cool! Well Remember that murder thing I mentioned?  Armello is a pretty rad indie game that simulates a stellar board game experience. One that mixes elements from Table-Top, Pen and Paper RPGs, and a bit of MtG to make for a very unique experience. Armello is pretty simple to play once you get the hang of the games systems. But its fairly complex to explain Despite a bit of a learning curve, this game is definitely worth the initial hump of What the hell am I doing?. Before we get into the nitty gritty, the main goal of Armello is to become the new Monarch. The current King has been stricken with an evil disease called The Rot. And as you would expect, hes not doing so hot. Every night his condition worsens, and every day he inches closer to death. The Rot also affects his mind, sending him into madness. I feel bad for the guy.  Now, how does this relate to the player? Well, every win condition involves usurping him, either by waiting for him to die and taking his place. Or taking the throne through force. Heck, even the condition that involves purifying the King of his Rot kills him. So you need to get comfortable with the idea of regicide. Despite its appearance, Armello is a pretty dark and rough game.  The death of the King is the impetus, and the final goal, of your actions. Almost everything you do will revolve around this end goal. But the King is more of a passive piece on the board. He looms over the game, and carries out evil machinations, but never poses an immediate threat. What you have to look out for is the three other people all actively scheming, and advancing their own plots. Youll be put in situations very regularly that involve you prolonging the Kings life in order to ensure youre the one to end it. The enemy of my enemy and all that.  There are a lot of moving pieces in Armello. Four players all working towards a similar goal. With alliances and rivalries beginning and ending on a turn by turn bases. What might appear like help from another player is really just them protecting themselves. Ill help you this turn to back stab you next turn.  Everything might be going exceptionally well on turn three, but by turn four the entire board state has changed and you must re-assess. It pays to think ahead, and have a plan, but it is invaluable to be able to adapt. There were many occasions where I was one turn away from winning, only to have it slip away from me when the AI pulled a total dark horse victory out of thin air.  How is this possible? Well, every player has a wide array of abilities that can, when used creatively, be applied to completely ruin another players day. There are pieces of equipment that increase your prowess in battle making it easier to kill the King or anything else. There are magic spells that give nasty status effects, such as: ending your turn prematurely, move you across the board, or possibly even killing you. And my personal favorite, traps. These can be anything from poison, killing companions, stealing their cards or gold, negating their equipment.. the list goes on. If you think through your actions, and use everything at your disposal, you can send someone in the lead into last place with one turn.  The order you do things in, and how long you wait to do it are incredibly important. On your turn you, usually, have three action points that allow you to do the various things at your disposal. Some take more than others Simply moving three spaces can wreck havoc on another player. Scattered around the games map are little villages. If you move your character through them they will pay tribute to you in the form of gold. Without gold you cant perform certain actions. Having three turns worth of set up be ruined because youre short one gold is incredibly disheartening.  The swings in Armello are fast and hard. Ive gone from first to last and back more than once over the course of a game. Its never dull, and never boring. The pressure is almost always on. And the games are fast enough that you can play one over a lunch break.  Aside from killing the other players, there are also quests you can embark on that give various rewards. Sometimes the rewards can be game winning. Other times they can be a massive disappointment. But youll always walk away with some kind of a bonus, like an increase in your stats and Prestige. If the King dies of his Rot, the player with the highest prestige is the winner by default.  Armello really requires you to think, and demands a good bit a strategy. The games go by quick so your plans need to come to fruition sooner, rather than later. I find myself planning for the end game on turn one. I want to win via killing the king. And adapting my play towards whatever will actively further that goal.  Its a good mix of long term and short term planning at the exact same moment. If you realize that things arent going your way, you need to adjust your strategy or risk losing. By the time you realize things are bad its almost too late. Its as much about furthering your own ends, as it is interfering with everyone elses. Because everyones position is so precarious, just a small bit of interference is enough to make someone target you the rest of the game   If I can kill the bear this turn, Ill lower their prestige enough that when the king dies two turns from now I can win. Or even better Well If I cant win, youre definitely not winning either.  Armello is a very mentally stimulating experience And Ive only played with the AI. So I cant speak for playing with humans. I have to imagine its a hundred times better. But, thats one of the best parts of Armello. The AI is actually very good! Now, once I got really acquainted with the game I was able to out play the AI fairly easily. But theyre still definitely capable of einschrauben mich ber, hardcore.  And on top of everything else Ive mentioned here. The game has some seriously great artwork. It has a great storybook style to it that is simultaneously both lighthearted, and very dark. Watching a cute little rat solemnly hand over money to the kings guards as they terrorize the townsfolk hits way harder than youd expect. Hes not happy about it but it has to be done.  Armello is awesome. Its worth every penny. Seriously, support the Devs. If you like strategy, check it out. If you have friends, and want something to play together that doesnt require a large time investment Armellos your game.  Buy it. I highly doubt youll regret it. Armello 10/10 After playing 5 online matches and winning only one I strongly feel Armello is a thrilling, fun to play turn based strategy with RNG dice and cards, neat animations and captivating gameplay. Combat is resolved with dice and cards both.    There is a really low learning curve, but lots of tactics, and it's easy to make a poor choice until you get used to the game which adjusts the general new player curve to about medium. The game so far is pretty much meant for multiplayer competitive play, you can play single player while you're searching for a multiplayer match, much like other games of simular orientation.    10/10 for it's genre, I don't give 10/10 lightly, i don't take the time to review a game unless i am insanely impressed with the budget + quality ratio.

A digital board game featuring lovable animal characters trying to dethrone a corrupted king and claim the throne for their clan. Mechanics are well thought out, and the game is regularly updated with new and improved systems to add additional depth while not making the game overly complex or confusing. There are multiple ways to win, which helps keep a single person from dominating the match, though the game is quite RNG-based, relying on dice rolling for battles, card drawing, procedurally generated board, semi-randomized quests, and a few other mechanics. Sometimes even with excellent strategy, the luck of the draw can't be overcome.  Still, an excellent game I never get bored of.   Game length: 1-2 hours  Pros: + Beautiful and unique style and graphics featuring anthropomorphic animals + Great soundtrack + Procedurally generated board means every game will be different + Multiple ways to claim victory, to stop a single player from dominating and blocking others from winning + Interesting and unique systems for combat, bounties, and 'traps' + Each character has a unique hero power that makes them different from other heroes + Each hero can be further customized to your playstyle with a selection of rings (exclusive to clans) and amulets (available to all heros) + 'Microtransactions' handled very well and very positively for everyone. Dice skins can be found in chests and traded or sold on the Steam market, which the Devs get a cut of when an item sells on the market. + Updated fairly regularly with new and enhanced systems + Devs are very attentive to bugs and glitches and do their best to solve them as soon as they can + Promotes public play with a chest and key system, in which both chests AND keys drop + Custom rule settings for private games + Can play a single-player match while waiting for a game (though queues are rarely very long), tab on taskbar will flash when you find a game while queued is you don't want to play singleplayer  Cons: - RNG-based, sometimes too much - Some hero's powers are almost useless, while others are very powerful - Private play doesn't give you keys or chests, making those who prefer to play only with friends unrewarded and left out (though the keys and chests only contain cosmetic dice skins, so it's not a mechanical disadvantage) - Currently a set of 4 exclusive Kickstarter heroes, though anyone playing in a private game with someone who owns them can use them, they can only be used in private games, and the Devs have stated they will be released as DLC for anyone to purchase eventually - Only way to communicate is through a set of 'commands', such as Hello, Good-bye, etc. No voice or text chat. - DLC is a little pricey, especially in comparison to the full game (the set of 4 DLC heroes is $10, 2 board skins are $5).

This wouldn't be that bad, if it didn't happen afte you'd already invested 45 minutes into a multiplayer match. Don't take my word for it - go to the discusson forums and the Bug section. I have about 250 hours in this game, so obviously there is a lot to enjoy. But I don't recommend you buy it until you start seeing posts here about these issues being resolved. It's absolutely infuriating, because this could be a truly great game, and instead it's something I come back to every few weeks, hoping will be better, and it never is.

And that's what it all comes down to, how smart, how strategic can you be with the cards you are dealt?  And can you accept how the die roll? That's LIFE PEOPLE, LIFEEEEE.  Anyways, enough life talk, let's talk about the game.  This game is not entirely down to luck, you can be smart about what you're given. Sometimes, you really will be cornered. But the thing is, everyone starts each game at square one. No one is OP, (at first) and the game can change in your favor or anyone elses. You can sabotage others and they can sabotage you. To me, that's very fair.  The die in this game are not pre animated, they physically roll as they should in real life, and they are completely random because of this. To me that's as fair as it gets.  If you're the type of person who cannot accept the fact that sometimes things don't go your way, then this game may not be for you. If you like the thrill of the risk, the fun that can be had by the fact anything could happen at anytime and you just might have the resources to counter anything against you, then this is for you.  The graphics are great, the music is great, it's easy to pick up and learn if you just play through the tutorial and try one single player game, you'll have a grasp of the whole thing.  This is highly recommended by me, it's incredibly fun, quite tactical and just plain good.  As an Early Access game, there are bugs. They don't happen often at all. But there were only 2 instances where 2 of my friends couldn't finish their games. All other times have been good. There's also a terrific built in bug reporting system for these instances as well. So yeah!  GET THIS GAME. Sale or not.

I've never felt compelled to write a postitive review about a game before, however Armello exceeded my expectations for a turn-based strategy game. In essence, Armello appears to be a unique blend between Monopoly and the Heroes of Might and Magic Series. However, Armello trumps both through its multiple win conditions that lead to relatively short, 17 to 20 turn games (from my experience).  Armello's focus on both random and non-random events to determine the winner of a game reminds me heavily of how Hearthstone can be played. In certain cases with Hearthstone, an individual card draw may win the game. However, there is always the aspect of deck building and card play order which can provide the stronger influence. Armello's strength by contrast, lies in the building of your hero's stats, equipment and buff usage throughout the game. As a result, Armello avoids the pay to win mentality of Hearthstone.  An argument I disagree with is that Armello can be criticised over its choice of unlockable perks for playing the game, which can potentially disadvantage newer players in the multiplayer environment. Firstly, a new player in multiplayer is far more at a disadvantage for lack of knowledge about the game mechanics than anything else. If a person plays a game without a strategy as to how they are going to win, they are very unlikely to do so. Secondly, the unlockable perks can be so minor in their impact, that they will not affect gameplay anywhere near as much as strategy or a good random draw.  TLDR: Armello is an excellent cross between Monopoly and Heroes of Might and Magic. The games are relatively short. It's not pay to win like Hearthstone. A good strategy is the most likely way you will win a game.

I really wanted to be able to write a positive review and recommend this game, but I just can't. It has fantastic artwork, and *some* fun game mechanics, but its flaws in sum are crippling, and in the end cause more frustration than enjoyment. The game suffers from a combination of excessive luck, snowball effect, and too long average game sessions accordingly. Far too often, within the first 2-3 turns, it's already obvious which one or two players will actually have a chance at winning, while the other two or three players got screwed by RNG. This would be OK, in a game that takes an average of 30 minutes. But to have zero chance of winning over half the time due to bad luck just ten minutes into a one-hour game is just not my idea of fun or enjoyable. For this game to be what it could be, they need to find a way to drastically cut down on the snowball effect, or give players more control over their fate. One idea I can think of is to add a deck-building component, where players can choose which cards will be available to them, so as to be more likely to draw cards that work together and help a specific build; think MTG.

Armello has now been released as a completed product for the masses, but despite really wanting to like Armello, I must be honest and say that I feel lukewarm overall.  As a note, I am a fan of Euro-style board games (IE: Catan, Carcassonne, Terra Mystica, etc.) where strategy plays a larger role in determining victory. Player tactics in these sorts of board games are what make them more involving, although, sometimes at the cost of a higher learning curve. Armello falls closer towards the opposite end of the spectrum and positions itself as a more casual and family friendly style of board gaming (IE: Risk, Monopoly, LIFE, etc.) where luck plays in tandem with a light layer of strategy.  Armello, however, leans its gameplay tactics a bit too much on luck. Randomization and dice rolls are a significant portion of the games mechanics and include:     Randomized card draws    Randomized quest locations    Randomized outcomes for quest items    Randomized dungeon exploration outcomes    Randomized spawning of banes and spirit stones    Dice rolls for battle outcomes    Dice rolls for peril outcomes   As a result, whatever semblance of strategy a player attempts in Armello is unfortunately negated a great majority of the time. The most well laid of plans will be foiled due to mere chance, not an opponent's cunning. I hope that subsequent updates can improve and address the strategic involvement, but as it stands, Armello is currently only good for the occasional, light-hearted game. I have a feeling it will resonate with those who are expecting it to be as such, but for those players expecting a board game that involves deep strategization and tactics, I recommend looking elsewhere or sticking to the tried and true classics.  Edit: I have replayed this recently after multiple patches. Armello remains more of a luck-based board game rather than a strategy-based board game. To be clear, this is not to say that Armello does not have strategic elements. It does, but it is in rather light doses. Most of the action involves mitigating uncontrollable circumstances arising from luck. Again, if you are more fond of Euro-style board games like I am, then this is not the game for you. However, it is perfect fun as a casual board game.

TLDR: Recommended ONLY if it is on sale for 50% or so, or if you are a fan of playing board games with family/friends. Very pretty game that can be quite engaging the first times you play it. However, stay clear if you are not a fan of 'luck based' games, if you just want to singleplay to play it everyday AND if you expect to win every session. That won't happen.    Full review: It can be horribly unfair, or it can be downright cake walk, like a lot of board games out there this game will really test your luck.  Sometimes you may start out with a lot of gold, thus you then would base your play method on playing a lot of trick cards to troll the other Heroes while you focus on getting prestige or something else.   Other times you may get a very rare and strong equipment cards, to the point where (as it happened to me on one session) in a few turns you could get a combo that gives you 9 shields at the start of every battle, making you pretty much unkillable in that way (they can still kill you with spells/traps/etc however).   And other times... well, you may get killed before the next dawn over and over. Traps, unlucky dice rolls, getting quest objectives that are on the other side of the map of where you are... and maybe then the King and his 'favorite' Hero will decide on next turn to strip you off all your cards or gold! Fun times indeed.  No single game session is the same, which is actually a good thing since it won't feel repetitive too fast gameplay-wise, and the game uses a card system for your items and spells, and they all come with animated pictures which are overall beautiful to look at. Overall, the art and design of this game is its best aspect in my opinion.  Unfortunately, it does get repetitive on other areas. For example, the game is really lacking on type of 'tiles' for the map (maybe something like water tiles which take 2 AP but make you immune to spells? or maybe something like a Dungeon-Fort that awards you with an item/card if you manage to defeat a strong enemy in it? just a few examples out of my mind right now), and on map diversity as well, with there only being 2 map types (normal and winter, which are only for asthetic porpuses), it really gets dull fast and it really feels like more could have been done with these aspects.  Length of each session is what I believe 'enough'. The game has a sort of turn limit since each day the King will get weaker and weaker until his health is depleted which ends the game session unless someone kills/banishes the king before that. This usually takes about 20 turns or so and overall each session tends to last about 2-3 hours depending on how fast players play their turns. After playing it for a while (say, 7-8 full game sessions) it will probably become too repetitive on its visuals, but gameplay should still feel fun and fresh every time you play, especially if you play with other people rather than the AI.  Nice game with evident flaws, but nothing that cannot be polished on future updates. And even if they aren't, its still a good game to play once every now and then especially with other people as you would with any board game.

This is probably the best digital boardgame I've played. And, yes, it includes digital versions of actual board games. I originally Kickstarted it way back when, and it remains one of the very, very, few games that I do not regret Kickstarting.  Things I love most about Armello:  1 - The visual design---especially character design---is phenomenal. At one glance, even if you're not familiar with the game, you can guess how a character plays. Thane (wolf with sword) is an offensive combat character. Barnaby (bunny with giant hammer and armor) focuses on equipment and combat. Elyssia (who is the best design character of all IMO) is a builder. The king's a lion, and his guards are faithful dogs. All the playable characters ooze personalities, kind of like a dark fairy tale Overwatch. This is actually the reason why I Kickstarted it.  2 - Just like how games like Hearthstone does things that CCGs not played on a computer can't do, Armello does the same with boardgames. Things that would be too tedious to keep track of or involve secrecy that's impossible in tabletop play can happen easily here. Some people view that as a bad thing because it means that hotseat Armello will never happen (the devs confirmed this). I find that a plus because with Armello as a hotseat / physical game it means it's slightly easier to choose a board game when I'm playing with friends.  3 - It's just a really good board game. I'm not a super board game geek (case in point, I don't even have a Boardgamegeek account) but I've played my fair share of games. And Armello is definitely in the top 10 of my favorite games. Maybe even top 5. The mechanics are interesting and mostly balanced (yes even that stupid bear with his spells). And it makes me say 'mmm this is clever' both on plays and mechanics quite often.  Biggest problems with this game are game length and NMA (no more action, essentially game ending bugs). It takes an hour or two to play a game with 3 human opponents, and while you can do things offturn things do get slow. I often multitask while playing, which I like but may or may not be a plus for you. The NMA bugs are annoying, especially given the game length, but I've only gotten them in 1/10 games in the past and haven't seen any since a few months ago (after the War chest update). The devs clearly love the game and update it pretty often with bugfixes and new content, so I'm pretty happy.

Armello is, quite simply, an incredibly well designed game.  It's basically a digital card game / board game hybrid which combines strategic decision making and multiplayer bluffing and politics with a moderate degree of randomness. Yes, most actions in the game are determined by dice rolls but if you use your cards efficiently this can be mitigated to such a large extent that the victor is nearly always determined by strategic play rather than luck (I personally have around a 70% win rate at the time of writing and trust me, I'm not that lucky) .On balance the gameplay works extremely well and creates interesting situations with a surprising amount of replayability. Armello is by no means a game which you binge all day every day (although you could if you wanted to) but it's fantastic for a couple hours of laid back fun every now and then.  The game has a theme and art style which somehow immediately reminded me of the Redwall books I used to read when I was younger. It's somewhat cartoony but in an extremely polished, non-comical way. The 8 different characters that can be played all have different playstyles and are, on the whole, surprisingly well balanced. Many CCGs released these days could actually learn a lot from Armello in terms of game balance because the same is true for the cards in the game. Even cards which are less obviously useful and might sit dead in your hand for a turn or two can still be 'burned' for beneficial effects in combat or in perils (traps basically).  The only criticisms I have are that there are still a few bugs here and there (the most annoying one being a bug that freezes the game when a player gains AP using Strategist or Hot-Rot Wine when it's not their turn) and that ranked mode has still not been implemented.  This is a real shame as the game definitely has the player base to support it. The amount of players seems to have actually gone up significantly since the game was released on Steam and it rarely takes longer than half a minute to find a game at the time of writing.  Overall, highly recommended.

The different heroes you play as all have their own talents and skills. Each clan has their own rings and coupled with the trinkets and artifacts you uncover during the game you can have a wildly varied hand. At first it seems easy but there are many things out to get you. You have to face perils, survive enemy players and mobs and get close enough to the king to stop him. I love the aesthetics of this game, it certainly feels and sounds like a fantasy adventure you'd want to be a part of. The animal motif fits the theme and the range of cards and effects makes this a deeply complex game. Definitely one of the best board games on Steam.
